entry.title: Why I donâ€™t do affiliate marketing on SaaSHub

link.title: Why I donâ€™t do affiliate marketing on SaaSHub

entry.content:
During the last year, Iâ€™ve been approached on a regular basis with requests to take part in various affiliate and referral programs. To be honest, some of them seemed decent and applicable to SaaSHub. For example, a VPN service. If we take the â€œBest VPN Softwareâ€ page, it is quite suitable for including an affiliate link to a relevant VPN service. SaaSHub could drive a few sales, and I could make some additional money. Perfect. Well, it is a bit more complicated than that, at least to me.

First, yes, I may make a hundred dollars through a particular affiliate program; however, each product will require separate management, accounting and collecting the money through a different channel. The overhead and admin will be more than I can afford in regards to time and energy. It is just not viable at this stage.

Second, I will always be trying to be as objective as possible with the product lists on SaaSHub. However, if there were affiliate links and the relevant disclosures, many people will start questioning how genuine the ordering of the products is. In essence, the cost of using affiliate links would be losing some trust even if you are trustworthy.

My â€œworkaroundâ€ is offering a self-service and very affordable product promo. It is that easy. As long as a product has been approved on SaaSHub, it can be promoted for $99/month. That subscription fee is nothing for the marketing budges of most SaaS products, and they can easily test whether it works for them. At the end of the month, there are no additional admin costs and I get one single payment from one source instead of 50 payments from 50 distinct sources arriving in 28 different days (if I were using affiliates).

In the end, I donâ€™t think that affiliate and referral programs are bad or dishonest. If one discloses them and doesnâ€™t promote â€œfakeâ€ products, they could possibly be a viable revenue stream. They just donâ€™t work for SaaShub and me and now.

entry.title: On always looking for opportunities
entry.content:
There are great opportunities - all the time. We just have to be actively looking for them. And we should be prepared to be able to catch the moment when it comes.

I went to a local Sushi place recently. Nothing exciting, however, instead of writing down my name and contacts on a piece of paper, I was asked to simply scan a barcode and fill in a very simple and unobtrusive form. Easy. Here in Australia, restaurants are required to keep a record of the who and when visited their spot so that if a COVID-19 case shows up, they can do a more effective contact tracking. OK, a few days later, I went to a different restaurant and was asked to scan a barcode again and enter my details. They were using the same service as my details were prefilled. All I had to do was click a big centred green button. How convenient.

On the way home, I was thinking about how this service was built specifically to cater to the needs around COVID. It was very simple and ALL restaurants around Australia and New Zealand, have to comply with this new requirement. I checked the website of the service, a SaaS product, its entry price was $19 per month, and they stated that 60,000 businesses around Aus and NZ were using them! Thatâ€™d be around $120,000 per month for a simple check-in app. Of course, you will have to spend some money on marketing and effort on your go-to-market strategy, yet itâ€™s a perfect example of catching the moment.

I, and I imagine many other makers, can easily build such a simple service in a month. Even better, a team of a technical and a sales person could bootstrap such a business quite easily should they see the opportunity and execute quickly enough. Yes, this requirement wonâ€™t last forever; however, Iâ€™m sure that many founders wouldnâ€™t mind making a million dollars in a year.

I believe that similar opportunities show up all the time. All it takes is being prepared so that you can execute quickly enough when you notice them.
entry.summary: There are great opportunities - all the time. We just have to be actively looking for them. And we should be prepared to be able to catch the moment when it comes.

entry.title: The 3 Day Domain Name Rule
entry.content:
I will share one of my little â€œsecretsâ€ that have saved me hundreds or thousands of dollars - â€œThe 3 Day Domain Name Ruleâ€.

The Rule

Whenever you have an idea of a great domain name, wait for 3 days, at least, before buying it.

Itâ€™s that simple. However, be warned, there might be an uneasy feeling that someone is going to grab the domain before you. It will be haunting you on the back of your mind. You have to resist it and stick to the rule. Both your future self and your money will thank you.

Also, you could be thinking â€œBut, itâ€™s only $8.95â€. Yet, itâ€™s more. Usually, a few times more. Let me tell you why. We, people, hate losing things that we own. Hence, once you own the domain and have put your credit card in, it is very very likely you will be paying for that name for a few years. Domain registrars are aware of that, too. Thatâ€™s why the registration price, on many platforms, is %30 - %50 less compared to the following up renewals.

Here it is an example with GoDaddy: Reg $12; Renewal: $18 (+50%).

Iâ€™d say that you will keep your shiny new domain, on average, for 3 years at least.
That makes ~$50!, and NOT $11.99.

.io domains are the worst. First, they are heaps more expensive - $54 to reg it and $60 to renew => a $174 idea ownership cost. What is more, they seem short, trendy, and many of them are not registered yet. If you are building a tech product, you will be lured into buying one of those. Do yourself a favour and either try coming up with a .com name or at least apply the rule and donâ€™t rush.

Now, back to the rule. At some point, after buying many domains and losing some money, I realised that my enthusiasm for the â€œgreatâ€ idea I had the day before would start disappering more often than not. Only the â€œgoodâ€ ideas stuck for longer than a few days. Then, I came with this rule of thumb for myself - never buy a domain name without waiting for at least 3 days after coming up with the idea of it. Iâ€™ve never had a single case when someone else would grab the domain before me. NEVER. The closest one was about 3 months afer I had the idea. The domain name was vivanotes.com if you are curious. To be honest, it felt a bit bad, as I still had the idea written down in my notes. Yet, I will most probably never build that project and have saved hundreds or thousands of dollars along the way.

Why 3 days? There is no scientific reason! Itâ€™s easy to remember, itâ€™s longer than a weekend and it works for me.
entry.summary: I will share one of my little â€œsecretsâ€ that have saved me hundreds or thousands of dollars - â€œThe 3 Day Domain Name Ruleâ€.

entry.content:
Donâ€™t ask questions that start with â€œWhyâ€ unless you want your counterpart to defend a goal that serves you. â€œWhyâ€ is always an accusation, in any language.

The advice of avoiding â€œwhy questionsâ€ is from the book â€œNever Split The Differenceâ€ by Chris Voss. If we think about it, how straight to the point is that? When was the last time someone asked you â€œWhy thisâ€ or â€œWhy thatâ€ and you werenâ€™t left with a bit of sour feeling. For example, many bosses would use â€œwhy questionsâ€ in meetings after something had gone wrong (â€œWhy did you do thatâ€, â€œWhy didnâ€™t we sell enoughâ€, â€œWhy couldnâ€™t we release on timeâ€, etc.). However, that might be counterproductive in many cases.

The better alternative is asking calibrated and open-ended questions that direct the other person towards solving your problem. Such could be â€œHowâ€ or â€œWhatâ€ - â€œHow can we solve this problem?â€, â€œWhat can we do to improve the process?â€, etc. Coming up with these non-why questions will lead to better results for both parties in most cases. Moreover, they may start flowing naturally to you once you remember to avoid â€œwhy questionsâ€ in negotiations as a rule of thumb.
